content: The typical loaf sticking out of the bag may indeed be a baguette, but in general the easiest way to identify a baguette is by its shape/size. The word “baguette” roughly translates as “wand,” “rod” or “stick.” This the traditional French baguette tends to be more narrow than the one in the photo. The French bread in the photo would more likely just be called pain, which roughly translates “bread” or “loaf,” and which I’m guessing American grocers are reluctant to call it for obvious reasons. I’m not saying nobody calls the bread in the photo a baguette (maybe even in France!), I’m just saying that it technically ain’t one. Here’s a picture of what I would call baguettes, for reference: Source: http://nymag.com/restaurants/features/22781/index1.html The photo difference is not so great, but the bite difference is tremendous.
